section.title: have to, don't have to, can and can't
section.sectiontitle: We use have to/has to + verb when it is obligatory or necessary to do something.
section.text1: It's obligatory to drive on the left in Britain.
section.text1a: You have to drive on the left in Britain.
section.text2: It's necessary for him to get up at 6 o'clock to catch his train.
section.text2a: He has to get up at 6 o'clock to catch his train.
section.sectiontitle2: We use don't/doesn't have to + verb when it is not necessary to do something.
section.text3: It isn't necessary to come to the party if you don't want to.
section.text3a: You don't have to come to the party if you don't want to.
section.text4: It isn't necessary for her to pay because she's only six.
section.text4a: She doesn't have to pay because she's only six.

section.title: have to, don't have to, can and can't
section.sectiontitle: We use can + verb when it is okay to do something.
section.text1: It's okay to pay me tomorrow.
section.text2: It's okay to go home now.
section.sectiontitle2: We use can't + verb when it is not okay or it is prohibited to do something.
section.text3: It's not okay to smoke in here.
section.text4: It's not okay to park here.
